figure.figTranscr:
Blake Newsletter
Volume II, Number 1
June 1, 1968
Front Matter
This fifth Newsletter includes our second annual checklist of publications
on Blake. The checklist depends a great deal on readers who send in in-
formation about articles, and on authors who send offprints. The more
such assistance we can get, the more comprehensive and useful the check-
list will be.
This Newsletter also presents our first book review. Originally it had
seemed unnecessary to review books, but it’s gradually become clear that
reviews addressed to Blake scholars could perform a function not otherwise
performed. We intend to be selective about books chosen for review; sug-
gestions from readers are welcome. (The new Blake Concordance will be
reviewed in our next issue).
Many Newsletter subscriptions expired with #4. It would be burdensome
to bill readers individually. The number after your name on the address
label indicates with what issue your subscription expires (or expired).
In the event that your records don’t agree with ours, we will resolve
the difference in your favor, but please let us know about this.
I expect to be away from Berkeley for at least the first half of this
summer. Experience shows that forwarding mail produces more difficulty
than anything else; therefore it will be held for me at Berkeley, and
Newsletter correspondence will be even more dilatory than usual for the
next six weeks.
—MDP
The BLAKE NEWSLETTER is edited by Morton D. Paley, Department of English,
University of California, Berkeley 94720. Subscription price: two
dollars for one year (four issues). Please make checks payable to
Morton D. Paley. Subscribers in Britain may remit Postal Money Orders
for 16/8; such money orders must be open and uncrossed.
Copyright 1968 by Morton D. Paley

cell.ref: Grant, Rose, and Tolley’s edition of Blake’s illustrations for Young’s Night Thoughts
The Guardian on the transformation of no. 17 South Molton Street to a betting shop
E.P. Thompson lecture on Blake’s background in artisan, radical dissent
Criticism in Theoria on Blake’s Songs
Minor additions to Blake bibliography in Peattie’s chapter on Blake
Frederick Cummings and Allen Staley, Romantic Art in Britain: Drawings and Paintings 1760-1860
A Checklist of Blake Publications, June ’67 to May ’68
cell.hi: compiled by Morton D. Paley with the assistance of Karen Walowit

cell.ref: 3. All the Evidence That’s Fit to Print

div1.p: This fifth Newsletter includes our second annual checklist of publications on Blake. The checklist depends a great deal on readers who send in information about articles, and on authors who send offprints. The more such assistance we can get, the more comprehensive and useful the checklist will be.

This Newsletter also presents our first book review. Originally it had seemed unnecessary to review books, but it’s gradually become clear that reviews addressed to Blake scholars could perform a function not otherwise performed. We intend to be selective about books chosen for review; suggestions from readers are welcome. (The new Blake Concordance will be reviewed in our next issue).

Many Newsletter subscriptions expired with #4. It would be burdensome to bill readers individually. The number after your name on the address label indicates with what issue your subscription expires (or expired). In the event that your records don’t agree with ours, we will resolve the difference in your favor, but please let us know about this.

I expect to be away from Berkeley for at least the first half of this summer. Experience shows that forwarding mail produces more difficulty than anything else; therefore it will be held for me at Berkeley, and Newsletter correspondence will be even more dilatory than usual for the next six weeks.
div1.note: The BLAKE NEWSLETTER is edited by Morton D. Paley, Department of English, University of California, Berkeley 94720. Subscription price: two dollars for one year (four issues). Please make checks payable to Morton D. Paley. Subscribers in Britain may remit Postal Money Orders for 16/8; such money orders must be open and uncrossed.
